message: By any measure, the year we just closed the book on contained momentous, even world-changing events.  Through it all, the people of our little corner of the world responded with the same qualities of optimism and determination that have served us so well through the centuries.  Whatever challenges we face in the coming year, we will no doubt confront them with the same spirit as we always have.  As we embrace the new year together, it remains an honor to serve you in the United States House of Representatives.  On this first day of 2017, Mary Grace and I wish you a happy new year and much health, success, and happiness.
NA

Though we were sworn in on the House floor yesterday, we still must sign a formal oath of office as we begin the 115th Congress. As always, it remains an honor to serve you in the United States House of Representatives.  I'm hoping for a productive term, moving forward with protecting national security, enforcing our border and immigration laws, and promoting economic growth and job creation.

I voted against the proposed change to the Office of Congressional Ethics in the first place, and then supported overturning the alteration.  This is the right course of action, and I’m glad to see that the decision was reversed.  Any changes to improve ethics oversight in the House should be approached in a bipartisan manner, with input from both parties.  In the meantime, President-Elect Trump is correct that we face large challenges as a nation, and we should be spending our energy in solving those problems.  I’m looking forward to the 115th Congress being one that will truly get things done and make American great again.

Last minute rules and regulations often run counter to the wishes of the people, as outgoing administrations rush to entrench the last pieces of a partisan or ideological agenda.  This is a layer of protection for American citizens, who should not be governed by unelected Washington, DC bureaucrats, who do not have to face the voters on Election Day. Burdensome and meddlesome regulations are stifling the growth of private enterprise and job creation.  These rules are often an attempt to force through policies that have already been rejected by voters.  This is an extra guard against that practice.

Kate Steinle, of San Francisco, and Derek Kichline, of Hazleton, are just two of the victims of violent crime at the hands of illegal immigrants enabled by sanctuary cities -- those jurisdictions which openly refuse to obey federal immigration laws.  In Kichline's case, his killer had been released a number of times, including by New York, another sanctuary city.  Too many mayors and local governments think that they are above federal law and place their own ideology ahead of the safety of their residents.  This bill will stop that practice by saying to these sanctuary cities, "If you refuse to cooperate with federal immigration enforcement, you will lose your federal funding."

Allowing the United Nations to move forward with its virulently anti-Israel resolution was a particularly shameful move by President Obama, who broke with longstanding U.S. practice and turned his back on our strong ally Israel.  The U.N. resolution the president declined to veto served only to isolate Israel from its neighbors, and the complicity by the Obama administration sent the clear message that the United States cannot be counted on as a faithful ally.  Worse, the resolution was a severe blow to the peace process.  I am pleased, however, that under President Trump, there will no longer be any confusion around the world, and the United States will once again firmly stand with our allies, the Israelis.

I am pleased to announce the new location of my Carlisle district office, which is now open at 126 N. Hanover Street in Carlisle.  The office will be staffed during regular business hours of 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. on weekdays, excluding federal holidays.  The office was formerly located at 59 W. Louther Street.  Come in and see us!

Talking to Fox News about my bill to cut off all federal funding to sanctuary cities - those jurisdictions which provide safe havens for illegal immigrants by refusing to cooperate with federal immigration authorities.  Look for a story tonight on Special Report with Bret Baier.  With President Trump in the White House, the landscape has changed, and I'm optimistic that this third try with this legislation will be the charm!

In a joint session of Congress today, presided over by Vice President Joe Biden, we counted the Electoral College votes, which was the final step in declaring Trump the 45th President of the United States. Millions of people responded to Donald Trump’s message of revitalizing this country and were united in their belief that their government had stopped listening to their concerns.  With my relationship with the President-Elect and his incoming administration, I look forward to having increased influence as we begin to strengthen our national security, enforce our immigration laws, and foster robust economic development.

It was another wonderful day visiting the Pennsylvania Farm Show -- this time the 101st edition.  My colleague, Congressman Tom Marino, and I always enjoy seeing everybody, and were fast on our way to finding some of the famous milk shakes!

Last year, 135 law enforcement officers gave their lives in the line of duty - the highest number in five years. We're displaying a blue light in the office today to mark National Law Enforcement Appreciation Day, and we say "Thank You" to the brave men and women who risk their lives every day to protect our communities.

In continuing to build support for my bill to crack down on sanctuary cities, I appeared on Fox News Radio to describe why its unconscionable for localities to ignore federal law to the detriment of public safety. We have to say to these mayors, "If you do not cooperate with federal immigration officials, you will lose every penny of your federal funding."

I've been in consultation with state Sen. John Yudichak ever since the news broke that the Wolf Administration was considering SCI Retreat among its prison closings statewide, potentially killing 400 jobs. Today I met with PA Corrections Secretary John Wetzel, asking him to convey my concern to Gov. Wolf about the appearance that there is a rush to make a decision.  I think it’s a good idea to take a deep breath and carefully consider all of the implications of closing SCI Retreat.  The Wolf Administration’s announcement caught the community by surprise and there is an understandable amount of concern and uncertainty among the employees and their families.  Eliminating so many jobs so suddenly would have a severe impact – not just on those families, but on the entire local economy.

I am pleased to announce that local fire departments and emergency response companies can now apply for federal grants to help with staffing and providing around the clock emergency services to their communities.  The grant application period has opened for grants for local fire departments under the Staffing for Adequate Fire and Emergency Response (SAFER) program from the Department of Homeland Security.  The application period runs until Friday, February 10, 2017 at 5:00 p.m.

The U.S. embassy in Israel is the only American embassy that is not located in the capital city of the host nation.  With this in mind, I have joined 101 of my House colleagues in urging President-Elect Trump to move our embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem as soon as he takes office.  This is especially important since the Obama Administration allowed the United Nations to pass a stridently anti-Israel resolution, contrary to our longstanding national policy.  We must stand with our Israeli allies.

You never know who will drop in on one of our district offices.  We had a group of college professors from all over the world stop by our Carlisle office today, in the country to study the U.S. form of government. Welcome!

Today I supported the first procedural step toward repealing and replacing Obamacare.  The monstrosity of a health care law never lived up to its promises: people were thrown off their preferred plans; they lost access to their favorite doctors; and their premiums and deductibles skyrocketed.  Obamacare was a mess created without a single Republican vote in the first place and in no way represented a consensus approach to fixing our health care system.  There can be no mistake: Obamacare was on the ballot in November, and the voters said they wanted a change.  I will be watching closely as this process continues, because as we move toward a full repeal of Obamacare, we must have replacement plans ready to go without delay in between.  This cannot be a rerun of the infamous ‘we have to pass the bill to see what’s in it’ fiasco.  We must have a functional replacement so that no one falls through the cracks.

The World Champion Chicago Cubs will be received at the White House on Monday, so I thought it would be appropriate to share this picture. These aren't the 2016 Cubs, rather it is the Young Men's Polish Association fastpitch softball team from Hazleton, right about 1972 or so. In the back row, second from the right, you can spot a somewhat younger Joe Maddon, who, of course, is manager of the Cubs today. That's me in the front row, second from the right. Just over my right shoulder, with the JS on his hat, is my brother Lefty. These guys could play some ball, and our opponents always knew we were from the coal region, since we were scrappy and never gave up. Just like Joe's Cubs showed in the World Series. Great memories.

On this day, we honor the life and works of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. an American icon and hero who urged us to look beyond skin color and into a person's heart and character. He preached - and our nation was founded upon - the idea that all men are created equal. This is our core principle as a nation, and let us remember that as we honor Dr. King.

Happy to see such cooperation to protect the interests of the community and correctional officer safety, as state and federal offices got together to discuss how to handle Gov. Wolf's possible closure of SCI - Retreat. My district director, Connie Falvello (all the way on the left), met with representatives of Sen. Toomey and Sen. Casey, and Rep. Cartwright, at LCCC.  Also happy to have Voices of J.O.E. represented, and the father of Eric Williams, the officer killed at USP Canaan.

My op-ed in support of my bill to defund sanctuary cities - those jurisdictions which refuse to obey the law or cooperate with federal immigration officials. This is my third attempt with this bill, but with the incoming Trump Administration, maybe there has been a change in the landscape. I hope we can find the political will in Congress to pass it.

It is impossible to count how many Pennsylvanians over the last year told me they were frustrated with Washington because they felt their government had stopped listening to them.  Today, the man who gave voice to that sentiment and pledged to return power to the people will be inaugurated as our 45th president. Mary Grace and I will be honored to be in attendance as Donald Trump becomes President of the United States.
Getting ready for the swearing in of Donald J. Trump, 45th President of the United States!  Got here plenty early. This will be my vantage point.

Even on Inauguration Day, the business of the 11th District of Pennsylvania goes on.  I sent a letter to Gov. Wolf urging him to consider all of the information before he decides to close state prisons, including SCI-Retreat, SCI-Frackville, and SCI-Waymart.  There are considerations of economic impact, public safety, and corrections officer welfare.  This is the governor's decision alone, but he should have all of the facts before a determination is made.

Today the world witnessed what is one of the finest attributes of the United States: the peaceful transfer of power from one chief executive to the next.  I thank former President Barack Obama for his service and wish him and his family well on the next phase of their lives.  And I welcome President Donald J. Trump and Vice President Mike Pence as they begin to travel their own path in blazing a new trail of American history.

The tax dollars of American citizens should not be used to further the brutal practice of abortion, whether it is in this country or anywhere else around the world.  If we spend public funds promoting the killing of unborn babies, we unavoidably make that the official policy of the United States.  This is wrong.  We ought to be protecting and celebrating human life, not using American public resources to endorse the ending of it.

President Trump has greenlighted two pipeline projects, which are tremendous victories for energy production and job creation over special interests and extreme environmentalist ideology. This will inject much-needed life into the economy, both nationally and in Pennsylvania, where workers in the manufacturing industry will benefit. Kick-starting these projects means jobs, but it also means greater American energy independence and lower fuel prices for consumers. There had never been any reason to oppose these pipelines, other than rigid ideology.  I am pleased that the barriers have been removed.

Americans have a wide range of opinions about abortion, but most everybody agrees that taxpayer money should not be used to pay for abortions.  The Hyde Amendment has been effective in reducing abortions, mostly those funded under Medicaid, but it was always limited in scope and required renewal each year.  This bill clearly states that the taxpayers will not pay for abortions against their will.

Today is a good day for those of us who have long fought against illegal immigration. These are all important steps toward securing our borders and beginning to finally enforce our federal immigration laws. I have been fighting against illegal immigration since I was mayor of Hazleton more than a decade ago, and it is wonderful to finally have an ally in the White House. President Trump has been true to his word, taking decisive action on illegal immigration inside of his first week in office.

This is a victory for the people of our region, most importantly, the employees and their families at the three facilities in our area.  The fact that these prisons will remain open will preserve hundreds of jobs and prevent a blow to our local economy.  Additionally, it will also alleviate concerns about officer safety, the burden on local courts, and the welfare of the inmates themselves.  I thank Gov. Wolf for listening to our point of view.

As a former mayor, I know the importance of sharing information between local, state, and federal agencies. I have seen this problem firsthand, and know that more can be done to help our local law enforcement get the support they need from the federal government. This bill is one small step to make the fusion centers a better resource for the people who know our communities the best, our local law enforcement officers.

The 9/11 Commission Report taught us that many times, valid travel documents are terrorists’ best weapons.  And terrorists want two things most of all: to be able to get into this country, and to be able to stay here. Almost half of the illegal immigrants present in this country came here legally only to have their visa expire – and then never left.  It’s why I have always said, if your state is home to an international airport, then you effectively live in a border state.

What an inspiration it is every year to see the giant crowds assemble for the annual March for Life in Washington, DC.  This year I am pleased to see that Vice President Mike Pence is speaking, which means the national news media will have no choice but to cover the march.  Thank you for all that you do in protecting innocent life.

We are a compassionate nation, one built on legal and orderly immigration, and one which has always offered a place for people seeking better lives.  Unfortunately, our enemies know this about us and are seeking to use our generosity against us.  We know that ISIS has expressed their intent to use our refugee program to sneak their fighters and sympathizers into our country because they know our security measures are lacking.  We cannot allow this

In a sense, the reaction from some quarters to President Trump’s executive order is understandable, because people are not used to a president who intends to enforce the borders of the United States.  It is the president’s job to protect the American people.  And it is also important to recognize that citizens of foreign nations simply do not have the right to unfettered admission to the United States.  What the president has done is to ensure that we have the time and capability to accurately determine the background of people seeking access to this country.
I'm getting ready to go on C-SPAN's Washington Journal this morning to talk about President Trump's executive order regarding refugees and seven terror-supporting nations. We'll be live at 8:30.

Happy to appear on C-SPAN this morning with John McArdle to talk about President Trump's executive order on the refugee program and seven terror-supporting nations. The order is legal, and a common sense approach to make sure that we know who is coming in from these failed, jihadist hotbed, states.

As a Member of the Homeland Security Committee and a former mayor, I have heard concerns raised by law enforcement in my district and elsewhere about the lack of information and coordination among federal, state, and local authorities.  This could well hamper our responses to terror or criminal threats.  My bill, passed by the House today, adds important requirements and accountability in how the Department of Homeland Security interacts and shares information.

Here's the video clip of my appearance on C-SPAN's Washington Journal today. It was a great opportunity to express my support for President Trump's executive order to address gaps in our vetting process for people coming from terrorism trouble spots around the world.  It was also a chance to correct some misunderstandings and misinformation about the order and its effect.

No one will ever replace Justice Antonin Scalia, but from what I have learned about Judge Gorsuch, he is a first rate selection as a successor. Judge Gorsuch believes in understanding the Constitution as it was written, instead of finding new laws and legal theories where none really exist. And he believes in interpreting the law, rather than creating legislation from the bench. He is a strong, conservative choice for this vacancy.

Growing up in the road construction business, I learned that private industry needs long-term planning and dedicated funding sources in order to invest in our nation’s infrastructure. It’s simply a fact that no employer will make plans to hire more workers or purchase million-dollar pieces of equipment without long-term security in government contracts. And no state or local government, being a former mayor, can make long-term plans without certainty in federal transportation spending.

The effects of the Obama War on Coal are still being felt, which is why we must get rid of this job-killing, unnecessary rule. The federal agency rewrote the rule with only a month left in the previous administration, placing a third of coal-related jobs in jeopardy because of the cost of compliance.  They ignored state input, and also their own studies that showed the rule would have virtually no environmental impact.  We stand today with coal miners, and also with a clean environment.

I regret to pass along that Punxsutawney Phil saw his shadow this morning, and according to his translators that means six more weeks of winter. This is the 131st year of Phil's prognostications (not the same groundhog all this time, presumably) and a statistical analysis of his predictions and the ensuing weather indicates that he has been right about 65 percent of the time.  Bill Murray was not available for comment this morning.

Warning! There is a new wave of email scams circulating which target company payroll or human resources offices and seek personally-identifying information of employees.  The IRS says the email scams may use a corporate officer’s name to create an appearance of legitimacy, a form of the email phishing practice known as “spoofing.”  The emails may request a list of employee names, salaries, and IRS W-2 forms.  The purpose of the information is to file fraudulent tax returns in an attempt to collect refunds.  If you think you have received one of the spoofing emails, forward it immediately to phishing@irs.gov.

It seems incredible that President Obama would use Social Security and a blanket policy as means to limit the lawful ownership of firearms, but that’s just what he did on his way out the door. This rule, stated simply, says that if your grandmother has anxiety and needs help managing her finances, she gets reported to NICS and is stripped of a Constitutional right.  That cannot stand.

I'm posting this again because of the misinformation and falsehoods that spread across the Internet last night.  This was a measure that the NRA, the ACLU, and the American Association of  People with Disabilities (among others) supported. It's a due process issue, and an issue of proclaiming people "mental defectives" simply because they need help managing their finances.

I'd like to recognize Catholic Schools Week for all of the great work that administrators, teachers, nuns, priests, and students do all year long.  About two million American children are educated by Catholic schools today, representing all races, ethnicities, economic backgrounds, and walks of life.  God bless, and keep working hard.

Looking forward to today's Homeland Security Committee hearing, where the new Homeland Security Secretary, Gen. John Kelly, will testify. I'll be asking him about President Trump's executive order on travel restrictions for foreign nationals who want to enter the U.S.  I support the president's actions to protect our national security.

Since 9/11, 23 percent of people arrested on terror-related charges have direct family ties to those seven nations.  And the young man who stabbed a number of people at Ohio State in November was a Somalian refugee. So, despite the complaints, the executive order is on target.

Here's some coverage of our Homeland Security hearing yesterday, featuring testimony from new DHS Secretary, retired Marine Corps General John Kelly. Contrary to the claims of some, there have been many arrests of people from the seven countries targeted by President Trump's executive order restricting travel. These seven are countries of concern for a reason - they are terrorist hotbeds and failed states which provide us no ability to check the backgrounds of individuals trying to enter the U.S.

I am pleased to report that I have retained all of my previous committee assignments for the new 115th Congress, including as a subcommittee chairman on the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee and as a member of the Subcommittee on Counterterrorism and Intelligence on the Homeland Security Committee.  I also will serve on the Committee on Education and the Workforce, where I sit on two subcommittees.
Best of luck to the Hazleton Area High School Cougars, as they take on Cedar Cliff in the first round of the PIAA Class AAA team wrestling championships.  The match starts tonight at 6:00 in Hershey.

One of the principal reasons I ran for Congress was my frustration with the federal government over refusing to enforce our existing immigration laws.  My City of Hazleton was overrun by illegal aliens who brought with them gangs, drugs, identify theft, fraud, and other crimes that I had to deal with.  No one was speaking for the victims of these crimes.  I always heard that we have to have compassion for the person who comes here illegally.  But I had to sit with people who lost loved ones who were victims, and I have compassion for them.  So I commend the Trump Administration for recognizing these crime victims.

Since the court decided that it has the authority to look at the reasons behind a presidential executive order, the least the judges could do is perform a simple Google search.  If they had, they would have found plenty of evidence that people from these failed states have been in this country and have been engaged in terror plots against Americans. The fact that there have been so many terror plots disrupted means that we’re asking law enforcement to play goalie after the terrorists are already roaming free inside the United States.

I look forward to working with the Trump Administration to undo the damage caused by the shortsighted and inaccurate ruling of the Ninth Circuit.    http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/feb/12/terror-convicts-came-from-countries-targeted-for-e/

I'm very glad to have the support of the Sunbury Daily Item's editorial board for my bill to crack down on visa overstays. While border enforcement is also key, almost half of the people who are in this country illegally did not cross a traditional border.  They came on a visa; the visa expired; and they never went home. This bill would make that a crime for the first time.

This legislation is intended to protect Americans, and other legal workers, from competition for scarce jobs from people who have broken the law to enter this country.  This clarifies that illegal immigrants granted amnesty by executive action cannot be issued work permits.

Congratulations to the Hazleton Area Cougars boys’ basketball team on winning their second straight Wyoming Valley Conference Division I title! The Cougars’ 14th title in 25-years, what an achievement!

That's why I led efforts in sending a letter to President Trump requesting that the documents be returned to the USDA website immediately. The American people deserve transparency, and must be afforded the opportunity to know what breeders, zoos, and research facilities are violating animal protection laws.  http://bit.ly/2kxPh34

Today, we honor the life of George Washington, for who without his courage to stand up for his beliefs we would not be here. This holiday has also come to recognize another president, Abraham Lincoln, both of whom have had an outside influence on our area, and deserve our respect and gratitude. In Carlisle, Washington worshiped at the First Presbyterian Church, which was built in 1757, and remains the oldest public building in Carlisle today. It is down the block from the new location of my district office, which is located at 126 N. Hanover Street. As Americans, I look forward to working with you to follow the examples of these two great leaders, by putting aside our differences and pulling together toward our shared goal of a stronger United States of America.

Today, I had the privilege of presenting long-overdue medals to United States Army Veteran Willis Eugene Negley. Willis served in the U.S. Army from 1952 to 1954 and served in Korea for 13 months. Our veterans have sacrificed enormously to protect our great nation and to keep us free from harm around the world. We are proud of Willis for his service and are truly grateful for his selfless actions in the Korean War. These five medals represent but a small amount of our regard for his heroism.

As a former mayor, I understand the infrastructure needs of local communities, specifically the road and bridge construction needs. The president's business-like approach to creating a robust infrastructure plan will address these important issues. Below is my op-ed in Highway Builder Magazine supporting President Trump’s plan.
Congratulations to the Holy Redeemer Royals on their District 2 AAA and the Nanticoke Area Trojanettes on their District 2 Class 4A championship victories this week!

I applaud President Trump's latest executive order and commend his continued efforts to improve vetting standards and ensure we have the time and capability to accurately determine the background of people seeking access to this country.

The president has shown he will keep his word and enforce our nation’s immigration laws. I look forward to working with the administration to continue securing our borders and keeping our nation safe.
Praying for Lt. Dennis DeVoe, his family, and the victims of yesterday's horrible tragedies.

Every family and business must operate under a budget and live within their means. With today’s executive order, President Trump is holding the federal government to the same standard.

When it comes to keeping kids safe, improving academic performance, and benefitting working families across northeast Pennsylvania, SHINE has a proven record of success. I look forward to working with the administration to restore this important funding, which has proven invaluable to our community.

I am disappointed with the two federal district court rulings temporarily blocking President Trump’s executive order suspending travel to the United States from six countries with strong connections to terrorism. Simply put: SHINE works.  I will keep working to restore this important funding source for our students and working families.

Every 25 minutes in this country, a baby is born having already been exposed to drugs and suffering from opioid withdrawal. I am proud to have worked on legislation requiring states which receive federal funds for child protective services to comply with federal law and enact certain guidelines for the welfare of children exposed to opioids. I look forward to working with the administration to ensure that it is implemented in a timely and effective manner.

BARLETTA STATEMENT ON AMERICAN HEALTH CARE ACT:  Obamacare is destroying our health care system.  The monstrosity of a health care law failed the American people by throwing them off their preferred plans, eliminating access to their favorite doctors, and sending premiums and deductibles through the roof.  In fact, the average premium in Pennsylvania increased by 32 percent this year, and in some corners premiums rose as much as 53 percent.  That level of cost increase is unsustainable.   I remain as committed to repealing and replacing Obamacare as I was on the day I came to Congress.  We must find an alternative that allows consumers to choose their plans, drives down costs, and ensures that Americans’ hard-earned tax dollars are properly distributed only to American citizens.    Unfortunately, after evaluating the text of the American Health Care Act, I cannot support the bill in its current form.  I am concerned that the bill lacks sufficient safeguards for verifying whether or not an individual applying for health care tax credits is lawfully in this country and eligible to receive them.  Under Obamacare, a half a million people received a total of $750 million in health care subsidies, even though the recipients could not prove their lawful presence in the United States.  I cannot vote for a replacement plan that fails to address this problem.  I came to Congress to stop illegal immigration.  I would have a hard time explaining to families in the 11th District – many of whom are still struggling to put food on the table and foot the costs of their own health care bills – why they should be helping to pay for the health expenses of someone who broke the law to get here and has no right to those federal dollars.  The repeal and replacement of Obamacare will be a multi-phase process, but until my concerns are met, I cannot at this point support the bill.

Millions of Americans can no longer afford health insurance under Obamacare, while at the same time, three-quarters of a billion dollars in Obamacare subsidies have been given to illegal immigrants. President Trump and Speaker Ryan agreed with me last night that this is wrong and must be fixed. The president gave his full support to legislation I will introduce to deny health care tax credits to illegal immigrants, and the speaker promised to bring the bill to the House floor for a vote. Because my concerns were met, I will vote for the bill with the understanding that my bill will receive full consideration on the House floor next month.

Today, the House passed legislation I co-sponsored to allow small businesses to pool together through association health plans and provide their employees with affordable health benefits.  The bill is part of the multi-step process Congress is taking to repeal and replace Obamacare with a mix of legislative and regulatory action to drive down costs and increase choice for consumers.

As we speak, Obamacare is collapsing. This disaster of a health care law threw people off their preferred plans, eliminated access to their favorite doctors, and on average, increased Pennsylvanians’ premiums by 32 percent. This afternoon, I voted to repeal and replace Obamacare. The AHCA is not the final product, but rather a starting point for a better health care plan that will drive down costs, restore choice, continue protections for individuals with pre-existing conditions so that they cannot be denied coverage, and ensure that Americans’ hard-earned tax dollars go only to American citizens. I also voted for a bill that blocks members of Congress and their staff from receiving any special health care benefits. Sticking the American people with Obamacare was simply not an option, and today we took a necessary step to repair that damage.

Despite false assertions, the AHCA retains the policy that nobody can be denied coverage based on a pre-existing condition and includes multiple layers of protections to maintain affordable costs for these individuals. Here's how:  Under the AHCA, nobody will be charged higher premiums if they keep up their health insurance coverage, and nobody can be denied coverage based on a health condition.  Additionally, the bill maintains that individuals cannot be discriminated against in the insurance market based on gender.    Obamacare applied a one-size-fits-all mandate on individuals and states, which forced insurers out of the marketplace and left individuals with and without pre-existing conditions either uncovered or with significant premiums and out of pocket costs. The AHCA, by contrast, allows for competition and for market forces to lower premiums.    While the AHCA allows states to apply for waivers to opt-out of certain Obamacare regulations, the state must first show how the waiver would serve to either reduce premiums, increase enrollment, stabilize the insurance market, increase consumer choice, or stabilize premiums for individuals with pre-existing conditions. Any state that receives a waiver will receive additional funding to support programs, such as high-risk pools, that cover costs for individuals with pre-existing conditions. If an individual in a state which receives a waiver does not maintain continuous coverage and experiences a higher premium as a result, protections will kick-in to ensure that the individual's rate lowers after a year. The bill was further amended to include an additional $8 billion specifically to bring down premiums and out-of-pocket costs for individuals with high health insurance costs in a state that receives a waiver.

It was an honor to be in the presence of five heroes this weekend who were presented with the Medal of Valor.    On July 4, 2017 the Shavertown Volunteer Fire Department, along with numerous other units from Back Mountain and West Side, rushed to the scene after receiving a report of a home fire where a victim was trapped inside.  Upon arriving at the scene, crews found two, three story, wood frame structures engulfed by an inferno.    Without concern for their own safety, a mixed crew from Truck 251 and Squad 251 stormed to the second floor of by way of the front stairs and over ground ladders, crashing through windows in a rush to gain access.  Both crews worked together and did a primary search of the second floor apartment. There Firefighter Keith Rinehimer first found the victim in a rear bedroom.    While attempting to remove the victim, Firefighter Rinehimer’s face piece became dislodged and he began to lose breathable air.  Still, Firefighter Rinehimer continued fighting to remove the victim.    At one point before leaving the bedroom, he was forced to remove his gloves to assist in holding onto the victim, receiving minor burns to both hands.  He was then joined by Firefighter Ted Sherrill, who assisted in removing the victim from the bedroom, moving her down a hallway towards the kitchen.   There they were met by Asst. Chief Erik Sowga, Captain David Rinehimer and Firefighter John Berti.  As the flames grew fiercer, it was decided that they would take the victim out by the front stairs instead of the ground ladders. They descended the front stairs amidst heavy smoke and fire conditions, with temperature readings at 800 degrees.    The victim, Lilou Warmouth, was removed from the building and turned over to EMS crews for transport. Firefighter Keith Rinehimer was treated at the scene for burns to both his hands and smoke inhalation, while the others were treated for heat exhaustion.    Incredibly, all five returned to service to continue to fight the fire.    Asst. Chief Erik Sowga, Captain David Rinehimer, Firefighter Keith Rinehimer, Firefighter Ted Sherrill and Firefighter John Berti all went above and beyond the call of duty on the night of July 4, 2017.  They displayed selfless courage and bravery, saving the life of Iilou Warmouth.  Their fearless courage deserved, and received, recognition with the Medal of Valor.  Firefighters and every first responder put their lives on the line daily to protect their fellow citizens.  Right now in California, thousands of firefighters battle infernos threatening towns across the state.  It was recently reported that up to 40 have tragically perished in the line of duty.   It’s incumbent upon us as citizens of this great country to recognize these heroes whenever and wherever we see them. Always remember when you pass your local firehouse, police station, military base or hospital that these are the men and women who will put their lives on the line for you.  They serve and protect innocent lives.  They actively take part in the highest duty of any nation: service.    I hope above all that we come together in fellowship and civic duty as Americans.  It is incumbent upon all of us to serve each other like these hero firefighters of the Shavertown Volunteer Fire Department

As the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act moves through the House Committee on Ways and Means, I think it is important to point out how simplifying, and lowering the tax code benefits American families.   In Pennsylvania, according to the IRS, 70.8% use the standard deduction when filing their taxes.  With an average income of $60,000, we give on average $8,919.45 a year to the federal government. Around 13.8% of Pennsylvanians also claim, on average, around $1,257.78 in child tax credits.   The current federal income tax system is too complicated and costly for all Americans. The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act streamlines 7 brackets into 4 brackets.  We expand the standard deduction from $6K to $12K for individuals, and $12K to $24K for joint filers--a clear benefit for PA.   Under the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, a family of four, making $59,000, will receive on average a tax cut of $1,182.  That's more money for families to spend how they see fit, for their needs.   The plan also increases the Child Tax Credit from $1,000 to $1,600--another win for PA families.  To eliminate waste, a social security verification from at least one parent must be provided for receipt of this credit.   These reforms are only part of the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, but I think it shows how we can create a better tax code for ALL American families. Let's let people keep more of their income to spend it how they see fit.
